Ask the Princess: Episode 1

This is the first in a series of posts entitled â€œAsk the Princess.â€ Â I am a princess and a polymath, and Iâ€™ve got lots of opinions and experience around various things. Â Topics covered here will be mostly about building APIs, but can cover martial arts, parenting, politics, or anything else anyone chooses to ask me about. Â Bring it on, Iâ€™ll answer with all the information and snark I can summon for your topic. Â  Â Without any further introduction, hereâ€™s the first column. Â The questions and answers are both mine. Â Send me an email or tweet with a question and I promise to address it in a future column.

Who are you, and why should I listen to your advice?

Iâ€™m Princess Polymath, and Iâ€™ve had a lot of experience as a developer, an evangelist, a mom and, well, a human. I have insight and experience to share, and lots of snark to season it with. Â If youâ€™re a developer or consumer of web APIs my questions and answers should be particularly useful to you, but Iâ€™m aiming for columns that are funny and fun for any humans who care to take the time to read them. Â My goal in life is to entertain, engage, and help people to get past frustrations â€“ and this seemed like another good tool for my tool belt. Â But since Iâ€™m asking my own questions, letâ€™s start with something easy.

Iâ€™ve got a great API but havenâ€™t had time to make any documentation. Â I want to release it right now! Â What do you think?

APIs arenâ€™t like other products. Â If a developer comes to use your API and ends up with a poor experience, theyâ€™re unlikely to ever come back. Â Remember that a lack of documentation, without any context for how itâ€™s expected to work, can and will result in an extremely frustrated developer, and theyâ€™ll do whatever they can never to use your system again.

To quote a trite but appropriate cliche, you only get one chance to make a first impression, and in the world of APIs the bar is high for a great first experience. Â Developers can get frustrated easily, and have little patience for someone who doesnâ€™t value their time and energy.

Make the documentation. Â Create some tutorials. Â Write and show sample code, and be available to give good support to your developers. Â Show them that their time is important and valuable to you and theyâ€™ll pay you back by becoming advocates for your system within their community.

I have a fantastic idea for an API. Â I whipped it up last night, and itâ€™s awesome!!! Â Why isnâ€™t my manager excited about it? Â Itâ€™s totally not fair ğŸ™

Sorry, Iâ€™m siding with your manager here. Â You made an APIâ€¦ to solve what problem? Â What is the purpose of the API? Â Creating additional interfaces into yourÂ system without understanding what they should be used for is really not gonna make for an excellent product. Â Your API has to be a first class product, and Iâ€™m sorry to say that skipping the steps of figuring out the business value and use cases, and how youâ€™re going to measure success mean that what youâ€™ve created is a toy, a hobby, and not a product the company will want to support.

If youâ€™re certain that your API is super awesome, you can actually back into the right information by figuring out use cases for your API and creating prototypes for them. Â Then determine what value this product can have for your company. Â APIs donâ€™t have to create money from thin air â€“ many of them arenâ€™t even going to increase monetization â€“ but they can make your main products better, more appealing, more accessible to your customers. Â You can improve the user experience, keep partners more engaged, and create more love and attention for your companyâ€™s system.

Just imagine youâ€™re trapped in an elevator with your CEO and youâ€™re trying to explain why you have an API â€“ and that â€œBecauseâ€¦ API!!!â€ isnâ€™t going to fly.

You have a lot of things to say about irresistible APIs, but my API is only for use inside of my company â€“ the developers are forced to use the system and so I donâ€™t have to worry about their â€œExperience.â€ Â So thanks for the thoughts, but I donâ€™t need them.

Ok, sure, you can think that way. Â But let me just tell you that in my experience, people who are forced to do something thatâ€™s unnecessarily difficult tend to become very recalcitrant â€“ nobody wants to be told how they have to achieve a goal. Â Sure, theyâ€™ll use your system, but a poorly designed API will cause them to try to figure out how to achieve their goals in whatever way they can, and theyâ€™ll likely end up pushing the edges of your system to try to achieve their goals, cursing your name the entire time. Â Without excellent documentation theyâ€™ll waste time attempting to figure out what the system needs to function. Â Without example code or tutorials theyâ€™ll use the system in ways you likely donâ€™t expect. Â All of these will create a much larger support burden for your team, and worse yet, these developers likely have the ability to escalate to your management chain and create trouble for you in the future. Â Take my advice, make a system thatâ€™s straightforward, well documented, and simple to use, and save yourself the headache and heartache of having to support cranky developers who have no choiceÂ but to use your system. Â Plus, maybe theyâ€™ll give you beer.

As a favor to my users, Iâ€™ve created convenience API resources like â€œlatestâ€ for the most recent item in a list, but they are whining that redirects arenâ€™t usable with complicated authentication schemes. Â Whatâ€™s *wrong* with these people???

Whatâ€™s wrong with you? Â My apologies, butÂ there are two different ways to approach problem solving in the development world. Â You can make things easy for yourself, but hard for your usersâ€¦ or you can do the opposite. Â One major goal of web APIs, REST in particular, is to create a system thatâ€™s simple for developers to use for integration and automation. Â Since youâ€™re workingÂ to make the system accessible for developersÂ using different languages, frameworks, or platforms, you need to keep this goal at the top of your priority list. Â Donâ€™t get lazy â€“ even though it may take a little longer to do the right thing, not doing the right thing can create a support nightmare.

For instance, in this case, a call to /my/resource/latest can act in one of two ways (from the developerâ€™s perspective). Â In the simplest case, they make the (signed) call to the latest endpoint and get back the correct information, likely with information about the resourceâ€™s actual URL. Â One call, getting the data back, just as the developer would expect. Â Youâ€™ll find that I yammer pretty constantly about making sure you donâ€™t surprise your developers â€“ much as UX experts talk about how important it is not to surprise your users. Â In this case, the developers are your users, and making them make two separate calls is certainly not what they expect. Â It seems like itâ€™s not a big deal, but consider the following:

  • Itâ€™s not a convenience method if the developer has to write code to make a second call. Â They might as well get the list to find the last member and then pull the correct resource. Â You havenâ€™t created a â€œconvenienceâ€ method if it requires the same amount of effort as existing resources, and youâ€™ve created an incorrect expectation by apparently offering something easier â€“ which isnâ€™t really.
  • More importantly, this process (making a call, getting back a redirect and then signing/making a second request) is *more* work than the more standard approach I described above. Â Most HTTP libraries can handle 302â€™s with grace, but many wonâ€™t know to re-sign the request with the authentication scheme when making the second request. Â So now, the developer who was able to use a standard library for their language has to update it to add new functionality

So, no. Â Making convenience functions or resources is a great idea â€“ but consider carefully how people will use those resources and make sure that your implementation makes it easier for your users to access the system. Â In this case, your server should do the work, not the client. Â Find the resource represented by â€œlatestâ€ and just return that to the client. Â Problem solved! Â Yes, itâ€™s more work for you, but a little extra work on your part will save a lot of time and heartache for your users.
